Brown previously served as a member of the [[Massachusetts General Court]], first in the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives|State House of Representatives]] (1998â2004) and then in the [[Massachusetts Senate|State Senate]] (2004â2010). Brown is a member of the [[Republican Party of the United States|Republican Party]], and faced the [[U.S. Democratic Party|Democratic]] candidate, Massachusetts Attorney General [[Martha Coakley]], in the [[United States Senate special election in Massachusetts, 2010|2010 special election]] to succeed U.S. Senator [[Ted Kennedy]]. While initially trailing Coakley in polling by a large margin, Brown won the election and in January 2010 became the first Republican elected to the U.S. Senate from Massachusetts since [[Edward Brooke]] in 1972. Prior to entering the state legislature, he had experience as a town [[Board of Selectmen|selectman]] and assessor. He is a practicing [[Attorneys in the United States|attorney]], concentrating in [[Property law|real estate law]] and serving as defense counsel in the [[Judge Advocate General's Corps, United States Army|Judge Advocate General's Corps]] of the [[Massachusetts Army National Guard]]. Brown is a graduate of [[Wakefield High School (Wakefield, Massachusetts)|Wakefield High School]] (1977), [[Tufts University]] (1981), and [[Boston College Law School]] (1985). ==Early life and education== Brown was born on September 12, 1959 in [[Kittery, Maine]]{{cite web|url=http://www.archive.org/stream/publicofficersof20072008bost#page/46/mode/2up|title= 2007-2008 Public Officers of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts|first=William F.|last=Welch|coauthors= James, Steven T.}} and grew up in [[Wakefield, Massachusetts]].{{cite news|last=Mooney|first=Brian C.|date=November 20, 2009|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/11/20/being_the_underdog_never_deters_a_driven_brown/?page=full|title=Being the underdog never deters a driven Brown |work=[[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate=December 31, 2009}} He often spent his summers in [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]], where his father served as a [[city council]]or for 18 years. The Brown family are of [[Scottish American|Scottish]] heritage.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Brown's father, Claude Bruce Brown, and mother, Judith,{{cite book |author=Brown, Scott |year=2011 |title=Against All Odds: My Life of Hardship, Fast Breaks, and Second Chances |publisher=[[HarperCollins]] |isbn=978-0062015549 |pages=17â18}} divorced when he was about a year old. Both his parents have since remarried three times. His father and his grandfather were Republicans. His father has said that young Scott became interested in running for political office in the mid 1960s while accompanying him on a campaign for state office.{{cite news|url=http://www.newburyportnews.com/punews/local_story_014234708.html|title=Brown's dad proud of son's political rise|first=Katie|last=Katzman|date=January 15, 2010|publisher=Newbury Port News}} Scott Brown recalls holding campaign signs for his father. Brown had a difficult childhood; after her divorce his working mother received [[welfare]] benefits.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2010/01/14/a_new_day_is_coming_restore_faith_and_balance/ |title=A New Day Is Coming To Restore Faith And Balance|last=Brown|first=Scott|date=January 14, 2010|work=[[The Boston Globe]]}} Brown experienced [[sexual abuse]] from a [[camp counselor]] who threatened to kill the 10-year-old boy if he told anyone—which he did not disclose even to his family until his autobiography ''Against All Odds'' (2011){{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/20/60minutes/main20032276.shtml | title=The resilient Senator Scott Brown | accessdate=2011-02-23 | author=Stahl, Leslie | date=2011-02-20 | publisher=CBS News}}âand physical abuse from his stepfathers.{{r|arsenault20110217}} During various periods of his childhood, Brown lived with his grandparents and his aunt. He shoplifted many times,{{r|arsenault20110217}} and was arrested for stealing record albums and brought before Judge [[Samuel Zoll]] in [[Salem, Massachusetts]] at the age of 13 or 14.{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2011/02/23/for_brown_second_chance_was_a_life_changing_moment/ |title=For Brown, second chance was a life-changing moment |first=Donovan |last=Slack |date=February 23, 2011 |work=[[The Boston Globe]]}} Zoll asked Brown if his siblings would like seeing him play basketball in jail and required Brown to write a 1,500-word essay on that question as his punishment. Brown later said, "that was the last time I ever stole. He graduated from [[Wakefield High School (Wakefield, Massachusetts)|Wakefield High School]] in 1977.{{cite web|url=http://www.scottbrown.com/Bio.htm|title=About State Senator Scott Brown|publisher=Scott Brown|accessdate=January 21, 2010 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080527023111/http://www.scottbrown.com/Bio.htm |archivedate = May 27, 2008}} He received a [[Bachelors of Arts]] in History,{{cite web|url=http://enews.tufts.edu/stories/1618/2010/01/19/ScottBrown |title=Tufts Alum Wins U.S. Senate Bid |publisher=Tufts University |date= |accessdate=2010-03-01}} [[cum laude]] from [[Tufts University]] in 1981 and a [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Boston College Law School]] in 1985. During his undergraduate career at Tufts, Brown was a member of the Kappa Chapter of [[Zeta Psi]] International Fraternity.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The Washington Post]] |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/16/AR2010011600851.html|title=US Senate candidate Scott Brown, at a glance|date=January 16, 2010|accessdate=January 16, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} ==Early career== ===Army National Guard service=== Brown has said the rescue efforts of [[Army National Guard]] during the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978]] impressed him. He joined the [[Massachusetts Army National Guard]] when he was 19, receiving his basic training at [[Fort Dix, New Jersey]], and attending [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] (ROTC) classes at the campus of [[Northeastern University]].{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/01/07/guard_service_a_key_to_candidate_brown/ |work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=January 7, 2010|accessdate=January 16, 2010|title=Guard service a key to candidate Brown|first=Brian C.|last=Mooney}} He was trained in [[Infantry Branch (United States)|infantry]], [[Quartermaster Corps (United States Army)|quartermaster]], and [[airborne forces|airborne]] duties, and in 1994 he joined the [[Judge Advocate General's Corps]] (JAG). He has been active in the Guard for about 30 years and has risen to the rank of [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]]. As the Army Guard's head [[defense attorney]] in [[New England]], Brown defended Guard members who had disciplinary difficulties such as positive [[drug tests]], and provided [[estate planning]] and [[real estate]] advice to those who are about to deploy to war zones. Brown has not served in [[Iraq]] or [[Afghanistan]], but said in 2009 that he was prepared to go if called. "I go where they order me to go... I'm just proud to serve and be part of the team." He spent ten days to two weeks with the Guard in [[Kazakhstan]] and a week in [[Paraguay]]. He was awarded the Army [[Commendation Medal]] for meritorious service in [[homeland security]] shortly after the [[September 11 attacks]]. He credits his military experience with causing him to focus on [[veteran]]'s issues as well as issues of war and peace. He has served on the Veterans and Federal Affairs Committee, the Hidden Wounds of War Commission, and the Governor's Task Force on Returning Veterans during his career as a legislator. On May 2, 2011, Brown announced that he would soon go to [[Afghanistan]] for training as part of his Army National Guard service.{{cite news| url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/05/02/scott-brown-headed-to-afghanistan-for-national-guard-duty/ | work=The New York Times | first=Michael D. | last=Shear | title=Scott Brown Headed to Afghanistan for National Guard Training | date=May 2, 2011}} ===Modeling=== In June 1982, Brown, then a 22-year-old law student at Boston College, won ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' magazine's "America's Sexiest Man" contest. After two weeks on a [[crash diet]] of "three cans of tuna a day" and intensive workouts{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2011/02/17/brown_describes_childhood_of_beatings_sexual_abuse/?page=full|title=Brown describes beatings, sexual abuse in childhood|date=2011-02-17|first=Mark and Christopher Rowland|last=Arsenault|work=[[The Boston Globe]]}} he was featured in the magazine's [[centerfold]], posing [[nude]] but strategically positioned so that according to Brown, "You don't see anything". In the accompanying interview, he referred to himself as "a bit of a patriot" and stated that he had political ambitions. The ''Cosmopolitan'' appearance and its $1,000 fee{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/jan/20/scott-brown-massachusetts-senator|title=Scott Brown: From Cosmo centrefold to Massachusetts senator|work=World news|date=January 20, 2010|first=James|last=Meikle|work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London}}{{cite journal|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/celebrity/news/scott-brown-nude-in-cosmo|title=Senator Is the Centerfold|author=Ashley Womble|work=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]|date=September 22, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010}} helped pay for law school, and began for Brown a "long, lucrative" part-time catalog and print modeling career in New York and Boston during the 1980s. ==State political career== Brown "caught the political bug" in 1992 when he was elected property [[assessor (property)|assessor]] of [[Wrentham, Massachusetts]]. In 1995, he was elected to the Wrentham [[Board of Selectmen]]. He successfully ran for the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] in 1998, representing the 9th Norfolk District for three terms. Brown again moved up the ladder of state politics to the state Senate in March 2004 when he won a special election to replace Democrat [[Cheryl Jacques]]. Brown was re-elected for a full term in November 2004, and again in November 2006, running without opposition the second time. He won re-election in November 2008, defeating Democratic candidate Sara Orozco by a 59â41 percent margin. Following his re-election, Brown was one of five Republicans in the 40-seat Massachusetts senate. In the Massachusetts Senate, Brown served on committees dealing with consumer protection, professional licensing, education, election laws, public safety, and veterans' affairs. In February 2007, a controversy arose after Brown's appearance at [[King Philip Regional High School]] in [[Wrentham, Massachusetts]] as part of a debate on [[gay marriage]]. The high school students had launched a [[Facebook]] group attack on Brown and had made a derogatory remark about his daughter, [[Ayla Brown|Ayla]]. During his presentation, Brown defended himself and his daughter by directly quoting several vulgar statements they had made and announcing the names of the students who had written the statements. Critics questioned whether Brown should have quoted the profane comments in front of a high school audience.{{cite news|url=http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/homepage/8998943093096972286|title=Brown on hot seat after quoting 'F' word at school appearance|author=Heather McCarron|work=[[The MetroWest Daily News]] |date=February 10, 2007}} In January 2010, ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' reported that during six terms in the Legislature, three each in the House and Senate, Brown had a modest record of legislative initiatives, but he had carved out a niche as a leading advocate for [[veterans]]. [[Richard R. Tisei]] of [[Wakefield, Massachusetts]], the leader of the Republican minority in the state Senate, called Brown "the acknowledged expert on veterans' issues."[http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/01/07/guard_service_a_key_to_candidate_brown/ "Guard Service a Key to Candidate Brown"] ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' January 7, 2010 State Senator [[Jack Hart (state senator)|Jack Hart]], a Democrat of [[South Boston]], said: "He does his homework, he's comprehensive in his approach, and on veterans' issues, he's one of them and has done a very good job on their behalf." Brown lists among his achievements as a legislator his authorship of a 2007 law that created a check-off box on state income tax forms for veterans to indicate whether they served in Iraq or Afghanistan. The state uses the information to notify veterans of available services and benefits, including the Welcome Home Bonus{{cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=veteransterminal&L=2&L0=Home&L1=Returning+Veterans&sid=Eveterans&b=terminalcontent&f=bonuses_gwot&csid=Eveterans |title=Welcome Home Bonus |publisher=Mass.gov |date=2001-09-11 |accessdate=2010-03-01}} that provides $1,000 for those returning from active duty in Afghanistan or Iraq. ==U.S. Senate== ===Elections=== ;2010 Special election {{Main|United States Senate special election in Massachusetts, 2010}} [[Image:Scott P. Brown.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Brown on the campaign trail.]] On September 12, 2009 (his 50th birthday), Brown announced his run for the U.S. Senate seat that became vacant with the death of [[Ted Kennedy]], saying the state "needs an independent thinker."{{cite news|url=http://www.philly.com/inquirer/world_us/20100121_Scott_Brown_proudly_proclaims_he_s__a_new_breed_of_Republican_.html|title=Scott Brown proudly proclaims he's 'a new breed of Republican'|first=Steve|last=Leblanc|agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=January 21, 2010|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/jan/20/massachusetts-election-scott-brown|title='I'm Scott Brown. I'm from Wrentham. I drive a truck'|first=Oliver|last=Burkeham|date=January 21, 2010|work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London}} ''Washington Post'' columnist [[Kathleen Parker]]{{cite news|last=Mooney| first=Alexander|title=Palin should step down, conservative commentator says|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/09/26/palin-should-step-down-conservative-commentator-says/ |work=[[CNN]] |date=September 26, 2008|accessdate=January 26, 2009}} said that Brown's political positions did not fall neatly into party lines, and called Brown "mainstream in a nation that defines itself as mostly conservative".{{Citation|last=Parker|first=Kathleen|author-link=Kathleen Parker|title=A Republican Senate upset in Massachusetts?|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 10, 2010|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/08/AR2010010803591.html|accessdate=January 18, 2010}} Boris Shor, political scientist at the [[Harris School of Public Policy]], described Brown as a liberal Republican by national standards, but well-suited for his Massachusetts constituency. Shor explained the support Brown was receiving from the conservative national GOP as due to their "decentralized decision" to support the candidate most likely to win.{{cite web|url=http://bshor.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/scott-brown-is-a-more-liberal-republican-than-dede-scozzafava|title=Scott Brown is a more liberal Republican than Dede Scozzafava|first=Boris|last=Shor|date=January 15, 2010|accessdate=January 16, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2010/01/scott-brown-is-liberal-republican.html|title=Scott Brown is a Liberal Republican|date=January 15, 2010|accessdate=January 16, 2010|work=[[FiveThirtyEight]]|first=Andrew|last=Gelman|authorlink=Andrew Gelman}} Brown won a landslide victory in the Republican primary on December 8, 2009, defeating late entrant and [[perennial candidate]] [[Jack E. Robinson III|Jack E. Robinson]] by a margin of 89 percent to 11 percent.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/feedarticle/8848591|title=Kennedy special election puts GOP in spotlight|last=Johnson|first=Glenn|date=December 9, 2009|work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London}} Brown's opponents in the general election were Democratic nominee, Attorney General Martha Coakley, and [[independent (politician)|independent]] [[Joseph L. Kennedy]] (no relation to the [[Kennedy family]]). At the outset, he faced overwhelming odds because he was relatively unknown compared to Coakley, he was running as a Republican in a very Democratic state, and much of his campaigning had to be done during the Christmas and New Year's season when citizens do not generally pay much attention to politics.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2009/12/scott_brown_win.html|title=Scott Brown wins GOP primary, readies for race against Coakley|first=Michael|last=Levenson|date=December 8, 2009|work=[[The Boston Globe]]}} No Republican had been elected to the U.S. Senate from Massachusetts since [[Edward Brooke]] in 1972.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/thefix/senate/scott-brown-wins-massachusetts-senate-race.html|title=Scott Brown wins Massachusetts Senate special election race|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 19, 2010}} He polled far behind Coakley for several months, but closed the gap in the early weeks of January.{{cite news|url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/politics/local_politics/poll-scott-brown-surges-to-double-digit-lead-over-martha-coakley|date=January 18, 2010|title=Poll: Scott Brown surges to double-digit lead over Martha Coakley|publisher=My Fox Boston}}{{cite web|url=http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/PPP_Release_MA_45398436.pdf|title=Senate Race Competitive|date=January 9, 2010|accessdate=January 15, 2010|publisher=[[Public Policy Polling]]}}{{cite news|url=http://insidemedford.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/ma-senate-poll-results.pdf|title=Senate poll results}}{{cite news|work=[[The Washington Post]] |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/08/AR2010010803591.html|title=A Republican Senate upset in Massachusetts?|date=January 10, 2010|accessdate=January 15, 2010|authorlink=Kathleen Parker|first=Kathleen|last=Parker}} A week before the general election, Brown raised $1.3 million from over 16,000 donors in a 24-hour [[money bomb]]. His campaign office stated it raised $5 million over the period from January 11â15.{{cite news|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news/politics/view/20100112scott_brown_claims_13_million_in_late_senate_donations/ |title=Candidates for Kennedy seat make final money pitch|agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=January 12, 2010|accessdate=January 15, 2010|work=[[Boston Herald]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/15/AR2010011504069.html|work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=January 16, 2010|title=Democrats scramble in Massachusetts to retain Ted Kennedy's old Senate seat|date=January 16, 2010|author1=Karl Vick|author2=Chris Cillizza}} Charlie Cook of the ''[[Cook Political Report]]'' stated on January 17 that he would put his "finger on the scale" for Scott Brown as the favorite. The Rothenberg Political Report released a statement that "the combination of public and private survey research and anecdotal information now strongly suggests that Republican Scott Brown will defeat Democrat Martha Coakley in tomorrow's race".{{cite news|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2010/01/18/bay-state-battle-new-indicators-show-brown-gaining-ground/ |title=Bay State Battle: New Indicators Show Brown Gaining Ground|first=Mary Lu|last=Carnevale|date=January 18, 2010|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}} [[Suffolk University]]'s polling of three [[bellwether]] counties on January 18 had Brown leading Coakley by double-digit margins.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0110/31621.html|title=New Poll: Brown Up 9|first=David|last=Catanese|date=January 18, 2010|publisher=Politico}} Brown won the January 19 election, performing well in traditional Republican strongholds and holding rival Coakley's margins down in many Democratic precincts.{{cite news|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/files/elections/2010/by_county/MA_US_Senate_0119.html?SITE=AP&SECTION=POLITICS|title=Massachusetts County Vote Results U.S. Senate â Unexpired Term â Special General|work=Associated Press |date=January 20, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/POLITICS/01/19/massachusetts.senate/index.html |first=Jim|last=Acosta|coauthors= Bash, Dana|title=Brown wins Massachusetts Senate race|work=[[CNN]] |date=January 19, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/01/19/polls-close-competitive-massachusetts-senate-race/ |title=Brown Scores Upset Victory Over Coakley in Massachusetts Senate Race|publisher=FOX News|date=January 19, 2010|accessdate=January 19, 2010}} [[Image:Senator Scott Brown 2010.jpg|thumb|left|Brown driving what during the campaign became his famous truck]] One week before the January special election, a controversy arose over a Coakley approved television ad. The ad referenced the [[conscientious objector]] amendment Brown had sponsored for inclusion in a 2005 proposed state measure on patients' rights.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2006/02/15/state_orders_wal_mart_to_sell_morning_after_pill/ |title=State orders Wal-Mart to sell morning-after pill, Retailer says it will consider stocking drug at all US stores|first=Bruce|last= Mohl|date=February 15, 2006|work=[[The Boston Globe]]}} This amendment would have allowed individual healthcare workers and hospitals to refuse to provide emergency contraceptive care to rape victims if they objected due to a [[religious belief]]. After the amendment failed, Brown did vote for the main bill which, along with other patient rights, requires healthcare workers and hospitals to provide such care.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/01/coakley_campaig_1.html |title=Brown's daughters call for Coakley to take down ad |date=January 12, 2010 |first=Matt|last=Viser |work=[[The Boston Globe]]}} Coakley's ad featured a male voice that said, "Brown even favors letting hospitals deny emergency contraception to rape victims," over the ad's graphic which had the words, "Deny care to rape victims." Brown's daughter [[Ayla Brown|Ayla]] called the Coakley ad "completely inaccurate and misleading", and stated that her father would never deny care to a rape victim. Brown criticized Coakley for running what he described as attack ads. In the 2010 Senate race, although Brown was not endorsed by the Greater Boston Tea Party group,The GBTP website states: "Please note that while a few Tea Party groups across the nation have endorsed either Brown or Kennedy, the Greater Boston Tea Party has not endorsed either. We are encouraging you to get informed, make your own decision and then get involved."{{cite web|url=http://greaterbostonteaparty.com/2010/01/massachusetts-special-senate-election-update/ |title=Massachusetts Special Senate Election Update|date=January 7, 2010|author=C Varley|work=What's Brewing|publisher=Greater Boston Tea Party}} the group organized a fund-raising breakfast for him in Boston.{{cite web|title=Brown campaign website notice|url=http://www.brownforussenate.com/event/2010-01-02/friends-tea-party-scott-brown-reception|title=Friends of the Tea Party Scott Brown Reception|publisher=Scott Brown for United States Senate|date=January 2, 2010}} The Tea Party Express also endorsed Brown{{cite press release|publisher=American Conservative Daily|date=January 9, 2010| url=http://www.americanconservativedaily.com/2010/01/tea-party-express-endorses-scott-brown-for-u-s-senate-massachusetts/ |title=Tea Party Express Endorses Scott Brown for US Senate Massachusetts}} and bought ads on the national cable networks supporting Brown.{{cite web|url=http://teapartyexpressblog.blogspot.com/ |title=Scott Brown Campaign: Shhh!!! A secret we can now share with you all!|date=January 18, 2010|publisher=Tea Party Express}} When told that at various times he has been labeled a [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]], [[moderate]] and a [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] Republican, he responded "I'm a Scott Brown Republican."{{cite web|url=http://theplumline.whorunsgov.com/scott-brown-transcript/ |title=Scott Brown Transcript|work=Greg Sergant's Blog|date=Undated|publisher=The Plum Line}} According to Politifact, while Brown was a Massachusetts legislator, he voted about 90 percent with the state Republican leadership;{{cite web|work=Politifact|url= http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2010/jan/18/barack-obama/obama-says-browns-voting-record-not-independent/ |date=January 18, 2010|title=Obama says Brown's voting record is not that of an independent}} however, Republican Leadership in the Massachusetts legislature is generally considered far more moderate than the national Republican Party.{{cite web|work=Boris Shor|url= http://bshor.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/scott-brown-is-a-more-liberal-republican-than-dede-scozzafava/ |date= January 15, 2010|title=Scott Brown is a more Liberal Republican than Dede Scozzafava}} On election night, after Coakley conceded, Brown gave a victory speech that stated, "It all started with me, my truck, and a few dedicated volunteers. It ended with Air Force One making an emergency run to Logan. I didn't mind when President Obama came here and criticized me - that happens in campaigns. But when he criticized my truck, that's where I draw the line."{{cite news|title=Scott Brown's Victory Speech|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/20/us/politics/20text-brown.html?pagewanted=all|first=Scott|last=Brown|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 20, 2010}} ;2012 {{Main|United States Senate election in Massachusetts, 2012}} In late June 2010, Brown was ranked as "the most popular officeholder in Massachusetts" according to a poll conducted by the ''Boston Globe''. 55% of those polled had favorable opinions of Brown nearly five months after his January 19, 2010, special election victory to finish the term of the late Senator Edward Kennedy. 50% of respondents generally approved of how Brown had handled his new position.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesunchronicle.com/articles/2010/06/29/news/7617880.txt/ |title=Sen. Scott Brown dubbed 'most popular' in poll|first=Michael|last=Gelbwasser|publisher=''Sun Chronicle'', Attleboro, MA |date=2010-06-29 |accessdate=2011-05-22}} On March 30, 2011, the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee released a poll showing that Brown remained the "most popular politician in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, with an approval rating of 73 percent." Brown's "'re-elect' score was comfortably above 50 percent, which is unusual for a Republican in an overwhelmingly Democratic state."{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/senator-scott-brown-in-good-shape-for-re-election-2011-3/ |title=Senator Scott Brown in Good Shape For Re-Election |first=John|last=Ellis|publisher=''Business Insider'', New York, NY |date=2011-03-31 |accessdate=2011-05-22}} October 2011 polling showed Brown's approvals had fallen and he faced a competitive re-election if matched against Democrat [[Elizabeth Warren]].[http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/2011/PPP_Release_MA_0920424.pdf One poll showed Warren at +2; [http://bostonherald.com/news/regional/view/2011_1003poll_warren_on_par_with_brown_joe_k_deval_would_do_better another] showed Brown at +3. ===Tenure=== Brown was sworn in to office on February 4, 2010, by [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]], in his capacity as [[President of the Senate]], on the floor of the Senate.[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2010/02/04/Brown-sworn-in-to-fill-Kennedy-Senate-seat/UPI-82741265303270/ "Brown sworn in to fill Kennedy Senate seat"], UPI. February 4, 2010. As a [[Classes of United States Senators#Class_I|Class I]] Senator, his term will last until January 3, 2013. Brown was among the speakers at the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] (CPAC) in [[Washington, D.C.]], introducing former Massachusetts [[governor of Massachusetts|governor]] [[Mitt Romney]].[http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/blogs/beltway-confidential/Scott-Brown-surprise-at-CPAC-84720617.html "Sen. Scott Brown surprise at CPAC"], The Washington Examiner. February 18, 2010. Despite his appearance at CPAC, where he alluded to his election as making "big government spenders...[not] feel good at all", Brown refused to rule out a vote for a Democratic "jobs bill" proposal, and has praised both [[Senate Majority Leader]] [[Harry Reid]] of [[Nevada]] and [[seniority in the United States Senate|senior]] Senator [[John Kerry]] of [[Massachusetts]] for indicating their willingness to work with him across party lines. {{cite news | url = http://news.bostonherald.com/news/us_politics/view/20100220scott_brown_calls_relations_with_john_kerry_surprisingly_positive/ | title = Scott Brown calls relations with John Kerry 'surprisingly positive' | work = [[Boston Herald]] | author = Jim O'Sullivan | agency = State House News Service | date = February 20, 2010 }} Scott was one of five Republican senators to vote for [[cloture]] on the [[Hiring Incentives to Restore Employment Act|jobs bill]]. The motion passed in the Senate 62â30 on February 22, 2010.{{Citation | last = Oliphant | first = James | last2 = Hook | first2 = Janet | title = Democrats block filibuster on scaled-back jobs bill | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = 2010-02-23 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2010/feb/23/nation/la-na-jobs-vote23-2010feb23 | accessdate = 2010-03-04}} In an [[up or down vote]] on the bill itself on February 24, 2010, Brown voted for final passage, helping to pass the bill 70-28.{{cite news |url=http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2010/02/24/2211029.aspx |title=Jobs bill passes overwhelmingly |work=First Read |publisher=[[msnbc.com]] |date=February 24, 2010}} According to the ''Washington Post'', Brown voted with the majority of Republicans 80% of the time.{{cite news| url=http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/members/B001268 | work=The Washington Post}} In the same poll, "56% of Massachusetts voters believed he has kept his promise to be an independent voice in the U.S. Senate."{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-paleologos/scott-brown-popular-in-ma_b_847084.html/ |title=Scott Brown Popular in MA Despite Voting With Republicans|first=David|last=Paleologos|publisher=''HuffPost News'' |date=2011-04-09 |accessdate=2011-05-22}} Brown's views on the 2011 budget cuts have been at odds with some of his fellow Republicans and Tea Party conservatives. His reluctance to go along with some of the more drastic budget cuts has placed him at odds with Glenn Beck and other prominent conservatives.{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/abraham/detail?entry_id=57868 | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | title=Scott Brown upsets Glenn Beck, Michelle Malkin, as Senate passes Jobs Bill | date=February 24, 2010}} He said he opposed these measures because he believed that they would have a negative impact on low income families and [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] in the [[Oval Office]], June 2010.]] Brown has positioned himself as a [[American conservative|conservative]] counterweight to Massachusetts' previously all-Democratic, 12-member congressional delegation. He describes himself as socially moderate and fiscally conservative. He identifies himself as a "[[Reagan Republican]]". He has said, "I'm going to be the only person down there who is going to be the independent voter and thinker... I've always been the underdog in one shape or form." ===Fiscal policy=== Brown is a signer of [[Americans_for_Tax_Reform#Taxpayer_Protection_Pledge|Americans for Tax Reform]]âs [[Taxpayer Protection Pledge]].{{cite web|title=The Taxpayer Protection Pledge Signers 112th Congressional List|url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/atrfiles/files/files/091411-federalpledgesigners.pdf|publisher=Americans for Tax Reform|accessdate=November 30, 2011}} Brown opposes a proposed multi-billion dollar tax on banks to recoup bailout money and prescribing of bank executive compensation. Brown, discussing the proposal through a spokesperson, said that he is "opposed to higher taxes, especially in the midst of a [[recession of 2008|severe recession]]". He also opposes it on the grounds that the tax would likely be passed onto consumers in the form of higher service and [[Automated teller machine|ATM]] fees.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/01/brown_criticize.html|title=Mass. Senate candidates clash on terrorism, bank bailout tax|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=January 14, 2010|author1=Stephanie Ebbert|author2=Matt Viser|accessdate=January 17, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.fresnobee.com/news/national-politics/story/1784255.html|title=Mass. Senate candidate Brown bashes Obama bank tax|date=January 16, 2010|first=Beth|last=Fouhy|accessdate=January 17, 2010|publisher=[[The Fresno Bee]]}} In September 2010, Brown opposed a Senate bill creating a $30 billion government fund aimed at encouraging lending to small businesses. The bill combines the fund with $12 billion in new tax breaks. Brown criticized the bill for including a provision much like [[Troubled Asset Relief Program|TARP]], stating: "Banks making lending decisions with government funds is not the way to get our economy moving again.ââ[http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/09/15/senate_oks_tax_breaks_for_small_businesses/ Small-business tax breaks clear a hurdle in the Senate 'Brown decries plan, calling it a new bailout; End of filibuster a win for Obama']. September 15, 2010 On December 12, 2010, the ''[[Boston Globe]]'' reported that "[c]ampaign contributions to [Brown] from the financial industry spiked sharply during a critical three-week period last summer as the fate of the [[DoddâFrank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Wall Street regulatory overhaul]] hung in the balance and Brown used the leverage of his swing vote to win key concessions sought by firms."Slack, Donovan (2010-12-12) [http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2010/12/12/banks_donations_soared_as_brown_negotiated/?page=full Donations poured in as Brownâs role grew], ''[[Boston Globe]]'' Brown received more than ten times the amount of contributions from the [[financial services industry]] as [[House Financial Services Committee]] chairman (and author of the legislation) [[Barney Frank]] during the same period. According to the ''[[Boston Globe|Globe]]'':
Brownâs efforts benefited large Massachusetts companies such as [[MassMutual Financial Group]], [[Liberty Mutual Insurance]], [[Fidelity Investments]], and [[State Street Corporation|State Street Corp.]], whose executives and [[political action committee]]s contributed $29,000 to Brown during the three-week period he was extracting the concessions from Democrats. They also benefited major out-of-state institutions such as [[Goldman Sachs]], [[UBS]], and [[JPMorgan Chase]]. Those and other out-of-state financial interests gave Brown a total of $50,000 during the period.
===Foreign policy=== Brown supports President Barack Obama's decision to send 30,000 more troops to [[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)|fight in Afghanistan]]. He cited [[Stanley McChrystal]]'s recommendations as a reason for his support. He also advocates that suspected [[terrorist]]s be tried in [[military tribunal]]s and not civilian courts. He also supports the limited use of "[[enhanced interrogation techniques]]", including [[waterboarding]] against non-citizen terrorist suspects.{{cite news|title=Brown and Coakley clash over terror suspects' rights|date=January 5, 2010|accessdate=January 19, 2010|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/01/05/brown_coakley_clash_over_suspected_terrorists_rights/ |work=[[The Boston Globe]] | first=Brian C. | last=Mooney}} He supports a [[two-state solution]] for the [[Israel-Palestinian conflict]] in which Israel and a new, independent [[Palestinian state]] would co-exist side by side. ===Veteran services=== In 2007, Brown wrote a law establishing a check off box on State income tax forms to allow a filer to indicate if he or she is a veteran of the [[Iraq War|Iraq]] or [[Afghanistan]] wars. The measure's purpose is to locate and inform returning veterans of benefits they qualify for. Known as the "Welcome Home" bonus, it was passed with [[bipartisan]] support. Brown also amended the [[DoddâFrank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]], with Senator [[Jack Reed (politician)|Jack Reed]] ([[Rhode Island|RI]]), to create a dedicated military liaison office within the newly formed [[Consumer Financial Protection Bureau]], which aside from defending against unscrupulous lenders, also ensures protection of military families against fraudulent life insurance policies. The measure passed the [[U.S. Senate]] 99 to 1.{{cite web |url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=111_cong_bills&docid=f:h4173enr.txt.pdf |title=H.R. 4173 (111th Congress) |publisher=[[United States Government Printing Office]]}} ===Health care=== Brown supported the 2006 [[Massachusetts health care reform]], which requires all residents to have [[health insurance]], with a state-subsidized plan created for those who cannot afford to insure themselves. Brown does not support President Obama's health care reform plan in its current form as approved by the Democratic-led House and Senate. He has stated this plan is fiscally unsound, and during his campaign notably pledged to be the 41st vote to [[filibuster]] the bill in the Senate.{{cite news | author = Browenstein, Joseph | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Health/HealthCare/scott-brown-win-massachusetts-begs-question-health-care/story?id=9615918 | title = Health Care Overhaul's Uncertain, Super-Majority-Free Future | work = [[ABC News]] | date = January 21, 2010 }} Brown voted for a state measure on patients' rights that, among other provisions, requires emergency rooms to provide what is known as the [[emergency contraception|morning-after pill]]{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Wellness/morning-pill-spurs-abortion-controversy/story?id=9700748 |title=Pregnancy Prevention or Abortion? New Emergency Contraception Pill Walks the Line |work=[[ABC News]] |date=February 1, 2010 |accessdate=2010-03-01}} to rape victims to prevent an unwanted pregnancy from developing. In consideration of health care workers who might have a religious objection to administering this medication, Brown attached what became known as the Conscientious Objector amendment which would have exempted these workers, as well as religious hospitals, from being required to provide this medication. However, Brown's amendment also required that all hospitals still had to provide a means for the patient to receive the medication, either by providing another healthcare worker willing to administer the medication, or, in the case of religious hospitals, to provide transportation to another facility, and in a timely manner.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/24/nation/la-na-scott-brown24-2010jan24 |title=What makes Scott Brown run? |author=Kathleen Hennessey |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2010-01-24 |accessdate=2010-03-01}} The amendment did not pass.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/01/06/in_debate_senate_candidates_seek_to_define_differences/?page=full |title=In debate, Senate candidates seek to define differences |author=Andrea Estes |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=2010-01-06 |accessdate=2010-03-01}} Brown remains in favor of allowing religious hospitals to refuse to provide emergency contraception on moral or religious grounds, as he stated in the January 5, 2010 candidate debate.{{cite web|url=http://media.969bostontalks.com/Podcasts/1466/010510senatedebatepart1.mp3 |title=96.9 Boston Talks podcast of the January 5, 2010 debate |date= |accessdate=2010-07-05}} ===Energy policy=== He supports expanding [[solar power|solar]], [[wind power|wind]], and [[nuclear power]], and [[offshore drilling]] exploration as a means to reduce the country's dependence on foreign oil. But, when faced with the controversial issue of whether an [[Cape Wind|offshore wind farm]] should be allowed in the waters off the Cape Cod coast in Massachusetts, a major tourist destination and boating location, he expressed opposition due to the fact he believed it would hinder tourism and boating in the area.{{cite news |author=Seelye, K. Q. |date=April 28, 2010 |title=Regulators Approve First Offshore Wind Farm in U.S. |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=April 28, 2010 |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/29/us/29wind.html?hp}} ===Social issues=== Brown refers to the currently legalized [[same-sex marriage in Massachusetts]] as a settled issue, which he does not wish to change. Brown has said he personally believes marriage is between a man and a woman, but would oppose a constitutional amendment banning [[gay marriage]].{{cite news|last=Hook |first=Janet |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation-and-world/la-na-scott-brown22-2010jan22,0,1805237.story |title=Scott Brown gets a hero's welcome from Senate Republicans |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2010-01-22 |accessdate=2010-03-01}} He is in favor of [[Civil union in the United States|civil unions]]. He opposes ending the [[Defense of Marriage Act]], but otherwise favors leaving the issue to the states to decide. After initially claiming neutrality on "[[don't ask, don't tell]]", the ban on openly gay military personnel,{{cite web |url=http://thinkprogress.org/2010/01/31/brown-dadt/ |title=Will Scott Brown support repealing Don't Ask, Don't Tell? |work=Think Progress |date=January 31, 2010}} he joined a handful of Republicans who broke with their party to repeal the ban in December 2010.{{cite news |url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news/politics/view/20101203scott_brown_ill_back_repeal_of_military_gay_ban/ |title=Scott Brown: I'll back repeal of military gay ban |work=[[The Boston Herald]] |date=December 3, 2010}}{{cite news|last=O'Keefe|first=Ed |title='Don't ask, don't tell' is repealed by Senate; bill awaits Obama's signing|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/18/AR2010121801729_2.html?sid=ST2010121803394|accessdate=2011-01-02|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=19 December 2010}} Brown has supported a presumption of shared parenting after divorce and was a co-sponsor of [[Fathers & Families|Fathers and Families]] HB 1460.{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/senate/Scott_Brown.htm |title=Scott Brown on the Issues |publisher=Ontheissues.org |date= |accessdate=2010-03-01}} Brown has stated that ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'' is settled law. He is against [[intact dilation and evacuation|intact dilation and evacuation abortions]] (known by opponents as "partial birth abortion") and has spoken in favor of [[parental consent]] for minors who seek an abortion. He said he would not use abortion as a [[litmus test (politics)|litmus test]] in [[Appointment and confirmation to the Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court confirmations]]. He opposes federal funding for [[elective abortion]] in accordance with the [[Hyde Amendment]]. ===Crime and security=== Brown supports strengthening Massachusetts sex offender penalties, the [[death penalty]],{{cite news|publisher=The Daily Caller|title=Where Senator-elect Scott Brown stands on issues â other than health care|first=Alex|last=Pappas|date=January 19, 2010|accessdate=January 20, 2010}} the [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|right to bear arms]] (with some restrictions such as licenses and background checks) and strengthening border enforcement and creating an employment verification system with penalties for companies that hire illegal immigrants. He opposes providing [[driver's licenses]] and in-state tuition to [[illegal immigrant]]s. ==Organizational associations and honors== {{Rquote|right|Scott Brown had a profound impact on national politics in the last year. His surprise victory upended conventional wisdom, inspired a legion of long-shot challenges, and energized Republicans and Democrats alike. Brownâs election showed the country that anything is possible, that no seat or incumbent is safe from challenge. And his maneuvering once in office produced the tiniest rays of bipartisanship in a Senate dark with dysfunction. For all of these reasons, he is our 2010 Bostonian of the Year.|Neil Swidey, ''[[The Boston Globe]]'}} Brown is a 30-year member of the [[Massachusetts National Guard]], in which he currently holds the rank of [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] in the [[Judge Advocate General's Corps]]. Brown was awarded the [[Commendation Medal|Army Commendation Medal]] for meritorious service in organizing the National Guard to quickly support [[homeland security]] following the terrorist attacks of [[September 11, 2001]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/wakefield/local_news/x1595355833|title=Wakefield son promoted to lieutenant colonel|last=Band|first=Gary|date=31 January 2007|work=The Wakfield Observer|accessdate=2 October 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scott-brown.us/ |title=Senator Scott Brown Army Commendation Medal}} He has also completed [[United States Army Airborne School|Airborne School]] and been awarded the [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]]. Brown has received the Public Servant of the Year Award from the United Chamber of Commerce for his leadership in reforming the state's [[sex offender]] laws and protecting [[victims' rights]].Suddath, Claire. [http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1954918,00.html "2-Minute Bio: Scott Brown"] ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' January 19, 2010. Brown's family has helped raise funds for such [[non-profit organizations]] as Horace Mann Educational Associates (HMEA,Inc.), Wrentham Developmental Center, Charles River Arc, and the Arc of Northern Bristol County, all for the care and support of those with [[developmental disabilities]]. He has also been recognized by the [[National Federation of Independent Businesses]] (NFIB) for his work in creating an environment that encourages job growth and expansion in Massachusetts.{{cite web |url=http://www.nfib.com/nfib-in-my-state/nfib-in-my-state-content/cmsid/50397/ |title=In My State: Massachusetts U.S. Senate Special Election News |publisher=[[National Federation of Independent Businesses|NFIB]]}} The ''[[Boston Globe]]'' selected Brown as the 2010 Bostonian of the Year, citing his "profound impact on national politics in the last year".{{cite news|last=Swidey|first=Neil|title=The Life of the party: Scott Brown|url=http://www.boston.com/lifestyle/articles/2011/01/02/the_life_of_the_party_scott_brown/?page=1|accessdate=4 January 2011|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=2 January 2011}} ==Personal life== ===Family=== Brown is married to former [[WCVB-TV]] reporter [[Gail Huff]], whom he met through modeling. They have two daughters, [[Ayla Brown|Ayla]], an ''[[American Idol]]'' semi-finalist and a student at [[Boston College]], and Arianna, a competitive equestrian and pre-medical student at [[Syracuse University]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/28/magazine/28Brown-t.html?pagewanted=all | title = Where Scott Brown Is Coming From | author = Frank Bruni | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = February 22, 2010 }} Besides their primary home in [[Massachusetts]], the couple owns a home in [[Rye, New Hampshire]], three rental condos in [[Boston]], and a timeshare on the Caribbean island of [[Aruba]].{{cite web|title=Financial disclosure, April 2009|publisher= Mass State Ethics commission|url=http://www.massinc.org/fileadmin/CommonWealth/Disclosure_forms/Senate/Brown_Scott_P.pdf|format=PDF}} {{cite news | url = http://news.bostonherald.com/news/politics/view/20100122compared_to_colleagues_scott_brown_lacks_green/ | title = Compared to colleagues, Scott Brown lacks green | author = Laura Crimaldi | work = [[Boston Herald]] | date = January 22, 2010 }} ===Religion=== Brown and his family are members of the [[Christian Reformed Church in North America]] and attend New England Chapel in [[Franklin, Massachusetts]]. They also have a relationship with a community of [[Cistercian]]s, more commonly known as [[Trappists|Trappistine]],{{cite web|url=http://abbey.msmabbey.org/ |title=Welcome to Mount Saint Mary's Abbey |publisher=Mount Saint Mary's Abbey |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2010-03-01}}{{cite web|url=http://abbey.msmabbey.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1%3Awelcome&catid=13%3Aabbey&Itemid=60&lang=en&limitstart=1 |title=Monastic Life - Page 2 |publisher=Mount Saint Mary's Abbey |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2010-03-01}} [[Roman Catholic]] nuns at Mount St. Mary's Abbey in [[Wrentham, Massachusetts]]. The Brown family has raised over $5 million for the order, helping to install [[solar panels]], a [[wind turbine]] and a candy manufacturing plant that the order operates. ===Plagiarism Controversy=== In October 2011, it was reveled that a section of Brown's website in which he wrote about the lessons learned from his upbringing had been lifted from the website of former Senator Elizabeth Dole.{{cite news | http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2011/10/scott-browns-plagiarized-message-whose-words-are-they/246675/| title=Scott Brown's Plagiarized Message: Whose Words Are They? | accessdate=2011-10-15 | author=Kaminer, Wendy| date=2011-10-15 | publisher=The Atlantic Monthly}} Brown's spokesperson remarked that error was a "staff level oversight". {{cite news | http://www.boston.com/Boston/politicalintelligence/2011/10/scott-brown-web-message-mirrors-elizabeth-dole-speech/86ZX3F3iZbJKdsoTL5vguN/index.html| title=Scott Brown web message mirrors Elizabeth Doleâs remarks on site | accessdate=2011-10-15 | author=Katz, Alex| date=2011-10-12 | publisher=The Boston Globe}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://scottbrown.senate.gov Senator Scott P.
